Title: Introduction to Static Arrays
Description: Think of a way to store multiple numbers
column7: like test scores. How would you do it without arrays? Now
column8: how can arrays help?
column10: focusing on their declaration and initialization. Students will write code to store and access data in arrays. The submittable artifact is a program creating and printing a static array of test scores.

Title: Accessing and Modifying Arrays
Description: If you have an array of numbers
column7: how do you change the third number?
column8: Students will learn to access and modify array elements using indices
column9: practicing with real-world data scenarios. The focus is on array manipulation. The submittable artifact is a program that modifies specific array elements.

Title: Input and Output with Arrays
Description: How would you ask the user to enter 5 numbers and store them in an array?
column7: The lesson covers reading user input into arrays and displaying their contents. Students will create a program to handle array I/O. The submittable artifact is a program that accepts and outputs an array of user inputs.

Title: Iterating Through Arrays
Starter: Why might you need to go through each element of an array one by one?
Description: Students will explore loop-based array iteration
column7: practicing with for and while loops. The focus is on processing array data. The submittable artifact is a program that iterates and processes an array.

Title: Sorting Arrays
Description: How would you arrange a list of numbers in order from smallest to largest?
column7: The lesson introduces sorting algorithms like bubble sort
column8: with hands-on coding exercises. Students will implement a sorting algorithm. The submittable artifact is a program that sorts an array.

Title: Introduction to Dynamic Arrays
Description: What if you don't know how many elements you need in advance? How can dynamic arrays help?
column7: Students will learn about dynamic arrays (e.g.
column8: ArrayList
column9: vectors) and their flexibility. The focus is on dynamic data structures. The submittable artifact is a program creating and adding elements to a dynamic array.

Title: Modifying Dynamic Arrays
Description: accessing elements
column7: How would you add a new item to a dynamic list
column8: like adding a new friend to a contact list?
column9: The lesson covers adding and removing elements in dynamic arrays
column10: with practical examples. Students will modify a dynamic array. The submittable artifact is a program that performs add/remove operations.

Title: Operations on Dynamic Arrays
Description: Why might you need to search for an element in a dynamic array?
column7: Students will practice searching and iterating dynamic arrays
column8: focusing on efficiency. The focus is on array operations. The submittable artifact is a program that searches a dynamic array.

Title: Introduction to Strings
Description: How is a string like a sequence of characters
column7: like your name?
column8: The lesson introduces strings as sequences of characters
column9: covering declaration and initialization. Students will manipulate strings in code. The submittable artifact is a program that creates and prints strings.

Title: String Comparison and Length
Description: How would you check if two words are the same
column7: like "cat" and "dog"?
column8: Students will learn to compare strings and find their lengths
column9: practicing with string functions. The focus is on string properties. The submittable artifact is a program comparing two strings and computing their lengths.

Title: String Operations: Copy and Concatenate
Description: How would you combine your first and last name into one string?
column7: The lesson covers string copying and concatenation
column8: with hands-on exercises. Students will write code to combine strings. The submittable artifact is a program that copies and concatenates strings.

Title: Advanced String Operations
Description: How would you find a word inside a sentence
column7: like "the" in "the cat"?
column8: Students will explore advanced string operations like substring location and insertion. The focus is on string manipulation. The submittable artifact is a program performing substring operations.

Title: Understanding Scope
Description: If you have a variable inside a function
column7: can you use it outside? Why or why not?
column8: The lesson introduces variable scope
column9: comparing local and global variables in functions. Students will write code demonstrating scope. The submittable artifact is a program with local and global variables.

Title: Declaring and Accessing Variables
Description: Where should you declare a variable if you need it in multiple functions?
column7: Students will practice declaring and accessing variables across different scopes. The focus is on scope management. The submittable artifact is a program demonstrating variable access across functions.

Title: Functions and Parameters
Description: Think of a recipe: what are the ingredients
column7: and how are they like function parameters?
column8: The lesson covers defining functions with parameters
column9: focusing on argument passing. Students will write parameterized functions. The submittable artifact is a program with a function using parameters.

Title: Functions with Return Values
Description: What does a function return if it has no return statement?
column7: Students will learn to create functions with return values
column8: emphasizing output handling. The focus is on function outputs. The submittable artifact is a program with a function returning a value.

Title: Default Parameters in Functions
Starter: How can default parameters make functions more flexible?
Description: The lesson introduces default parameters
column7: showing their use in flexible function design. Students will write functions with defaults. The submittable artifact is a program using default parameters.

Title: Functional Decomposition
Description: Code cleanup: Highlight redundant code in a sample program
column7: discuss how to simplify.
column8: Students will learn functional decomposition to simplify code by creating reusable functions. The focus is on code modularity. The submittable artifact is a refactored program with decomposed functions.

Title: Characteristics of Well-Defined Functions
Description: maintainability
column7: Why is it important for functions to be easy to read and maintain?
column8: The lesson covers characteristics of well-defined functions
column9: emphasizing readability and maintainability. Students will analyze function quality. The submittable artifact is a written critique of a function’s design.

Title: Functions Review
Description: return values
column7: exceptions
column8: Flashcard review: Match function concepts to definitions in pairs.
column9: Students will review function concepts through interactive exercises and coding practice. The focus is on reinforcing Strand 3 skills. The submittable artifact is a completed review worksheet with function examples.

Title: Using Built-in Classes
Description: Think of a car: what can you do with a car object
column7: like drive or honk?
column8: The lesson introduces built-in classes
column9: focusing on object instantiation and method calls. Students will use a built-in class in code. The submittable artifact is a program using a built-in class.

Title: Data Members and Member Functions
Description: How are data members like properties of an object
column7: like a car's color?
column8: Students will explore data members and member functions in object-oriented programming. The focus is on object properties. The submittable artifact is a program accessing object data members.

Title: Creating User-Defined Classes
Description: constructors
column7: How would you create a class for a student
column8: with name and grade?
column9: The lesson covers creating user-defined classes with constructors and data members. Students will design a custom class. The submittable artifact is a program defining a user-defined class.

Title: Constructors and Member Functions
Description: Why do we need a constructor when creating a class?
column7: Students will learn to define constructors and member functions for custom classes. The focus is on class implementation. The submittable artifact is a program with a class and constructor.

Title: OOP Review
Description: methods
column7: inheritance
column8: Group discussion: What are the key differences between classes and objects?
column9: The lesson reviews object-oriented programming concepts through discussion and coding. Students will reinforce class knowledge. The submittable artifact is a concept map of OOP principles.

Title: Introduction to File Handling
Description: How would you save a list of names to a file for later use?
column7: Students will learn to create and write to sequential files
column8: focusing on data persistence. The lesson includes file I/O coding. The submittable artifact is a program that writes data to a file.

Title: Reading and Writing Files
Description: How would you read data from a file and display it?
column7: The lesson covers reading and updating file data
column8: with practical file I/O exercises. Students will manipulate file contents. The submittable artifact is a program that reads and updates a file.

Title: File Operations
Description: What happens if you try to read from a file that doesn't exist?
column7: Students will explore advanced file operations
column8: including error handling for file access. The focus is on robust file management. The submittable artifact is a program with file error handling.

Title: Code Comprehension: Tracing
Description: Follow the flow: Trace a simple program and predict its output.
column7: The lesson focuses on tracing code execution to understand program flow. Students will practice tracing exercises. The submittable artifact is a trace table for a given program.

Title: Debugging with IDEs
Description: Error detective: Identify errors in a sample code snippet
column7: categorize them.
column8: Students will learn to use IDE debugging tools to identify and fix errors. The focus is on debugging techniques. The submittable artifact is a debugged program with error annotations.

Title: Testing for Robustness
Description: How would you test a program to make sure it handles invalid inputs?
column7: The lesson covers testing code for robustness
column8: focusing on edge cases. Students will create test cases. The submittable artifact is a test plan with five edge case tests.

Title: Project Planning
Description: What kind of program do you want to create? What features should it have?
column7: Students will plan a programming project
column8: defining specifications and data structures. The focus is on project design. The submittable artifact is a project specification document.

Title: Designing the Project
Description: Let's sketch out the steps your program will take.
column7: The lesson focuses on designing project algorithms using pseudocode and diagrams. Students will create a project blueprint. The submittable artifact is a pseudocode and UML diagram set.

Title: Implementing the Project
Description: document the project
column7: Code studio: Build
column8: test
column10: Students will implement and test their project
column11: applying Strand 6 concepts. The focus is on coding and documentation. The submittable artifact is the project code and documentation.

Title: Teamwork in Projects
Description: meet deadlines
column7: Team role play: Assign roles like leader
column8: coder
column10: The lesson emphasizes teamwork in project development
column11: with role assignments and coordination. Students will simulate team dynamics. The submittable artifact is a team task division plan.

Title: Ethics in Software Development
Description: Have you heard of any software that caused problems because it wasn't reliable? What happened?
column7: Students will explore software reliability and its societal impact through case studies. The focus is on ethical programming. The submittable artifact is a case study analysis.

Title: Security and Privacy
Description: How can software protect user data
column7: like passwords?
column8: The lesson covers security and privacy in software
column9: with discussions on data protection. Students will analyze security practices. The submittable artifact is a written plan for securing user data.

Title: Automation and Society
Description: Discuss: How does automation affect jobs
column7: both positively and negatively?
column8: Students will examine automation’s societal effects
column9: debating its pros and cons. The focus is on ethical considerations. The submittable artifact is a debate position paper on automation.

Title: Careers in Programming
Concepts: Different roles in a programming team
Starter: What kind of job would you like to have in the tech industry? Why?
Description: The lesson explores programming careers
column7: focusing on team roles like analyst and developer. Students will research a role. The submittable artifact is a one-page career profile.

Title: Trends and Pathways
Description: Trend debate: Is AI programming a boon or a risk for future careers?
column7: Students will investigate programming trends and career pathways
column8: discussing future opportunities. The focus is on industry trends. The submittable artifact is a presentation on a programming trend.
